head.title: Ford and G. M. Plan to End Use of Chlorofluorocarbons

hedline.hl1: Ford and G. M. Plan to End Use of Chlorofluorocarbons

block.p: LEAD: The two largest American auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, said today that they planned to eliminate chlorofluorocarbons in manufacturing and in vehicles by the mid-1990's.

The two largest American auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, said today that they planned to eliminate chlorofluorocarbons in manufacturing and in vehicles by the mid-1990's.
Chrysler has pledged to try to eliminate their use as soon as possible, but has not cited a specific date, a company spokesman said.

Automobile air conditioning systems use large quantities of freon, a form of chlorofluorocarbons, which have been found to damage the earth's protective ozone layer. Auto makers also use the chemical to make foam products and as solvents for removing grease from parts. G.M. and Ford said they planned to eliminate the chemical for these uses first, starting in 1993.
G.M. said it would begin phasing out chlorofluorocarbons in air conditioners with the 1994 models. Ford said it would take a year or two longer to do so.
But G.M. said the chemical would not be fully phased out until it could redesign its air conditioning systems, which will take at least four years.

Last month President Bush unveiled his proposals for a new clean air bill but did not address the issue of chlorofluorocarbons. In 1987, the United States and other nations agreed to cut the use of the chemicals in half by 1998.
